'''Wisdom''' is the ability to think and act using [[knowledge]], [[experience]], [[understanding]], [[common sense]], and [[insight]].<ref>"wisdom." Collins English Dictionary - Complete & Unabridged 10th Edition. HarperCollins Publishers. 28 Feb. 2014. <Dictionary.com http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/wisdom>.</ref> Wisdom has been regarded as one of four [[cardinal virtues]]; and as a [[virtue]], it is a habit or disposition to perform the action with the highest degree of adequacy under any given circumstance. This implies a possession of [[knowledge]] or the seeking thereof in order to apply it to the given circumstance. This involves an understanding of people, things, events, situations, and the willingness as well as the ability to apply perception, judgement, and action in keeping with the understanding of what is the optimal course of action. It often requires control of one's emotional reactions (the "[[Passions (philosophy)|passions]]") so that the universal principle of reason prevails to determine one's action. In short, wisdom is a disposition to find the truth coupled with an optimum judgement as to what actions should be taken in order to deliver the correct outcome.

==Definitions==
−
A basic definition of wisdom is the judicious application of [[knowledge]].<ref>"Wisdom is the right use of knowledge." – [[Charles Haddon Spurgeon]] (1834–1892)</ref> The opposite of wisdom is [[Foolishness|folly]]. Synonyms include [[prudence]], [[wikt:sagacity|sagacity]], [[discernment]], or insight.
+
[[Charles Haddon Spurgeon]] defined wisdom to be "the right use of [[knowledge]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=Charles Spurgeon|url=https://en.wikiquote.org/wiki/Charles_Spurgeon#Quotes|publisher=Wikiquote|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref> [[Robert I. Sutton]] and [[Andrew Hargadon]] defined the "attitude of wisdom" to be "acting with knowledge while doubting what one knows."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Carney|first1=Brian M.|last2=Getz|first2=Isaac|title=Freedom, Inc.|date=2009|publisher=Crown Business|isbn=9780307462473|page=238|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=J3nVgNxrvlwC&lpg=PA238&ots=sqbFWLiosK&dq=Wisdom%20acting%20knowledge%20doubting&pg=PA238#v=onepage&q=Wisdom%20acting%20knowledge%20doubting&f=false|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>
